verses.text: In the seventeenth year of Pekah the son of Remaliah, Ahaz the son of Jotham, king of Judah, became king.
verses.comment: No significant difference; standard introductory formula.

verses.text: Ahaz was twenty years old when he began to reign, and he reigned sixteen years in Jerusalem. He did not do what was right in the eyes of the LORD his God, like David his father.
verses.comment: Modernized 'did not do right'; retains detail of age and reign.

verses.text: But he walked in the ways of the kings of Israel, and even made his son pass through the fire, following the abominations of the nations whom the LORD had driven out before the children of Israel.
verses.comment: 'Pass through the fire' retains literal sense; see cross-referenced laws forbidding child sacrifice.

verses.text: He sacrificed and burned incense on the high places, on the hills, and under every green tree.
verses.comment: Preserves location list; matches Hebrew phrasing.

verses.text: Then Rezin king of Syria and Pekah son of Remaliah king of Israel came up to Jerusalem to wage war. They besieged Ahaz but could not overcome him.
verses.comment: Retains traditional names; 'besieged but could not overcome.'

verses.text: At that time Rezin king of Syria recovered Elath for Syria, and drove the people of Judah from Elath; the Edomites came to Elath and have lived there to this day.
verses.comment: Modern detail on occupation; 'Edomites' for 'Arameans.'

verses.text: So Ahaz sent messengers to Tiglath-pileser king of Assyria, saying, 'I am your servant and your son. Come up and save me from the hand of the king of Syria and from the hand of the king of Israel who are attacking me.'
verses.comment: Retains literal speech 'your servant and your son.'

verses.text: Ahaz took the silver and gold found in the house of the LORD and in the treasuries of the king’s house, and sent it as a gift to the king of Assyria.
verses.comment: Modernizes 'present' to 'gift.'

verses.text: The king of Assyria listened to him, so the king of Assyria went up against Damascus, captured it, and carried its people captive to Kir, and killed Rezin.
verses.comment: Retains names; matches sequence of events.

verses.text: King Ahaz went to Damascus to meet Tiglath-pileser king of Assyria. He saw the altar that was at Damascus, and King Ahaz sent to Uriah the priest a model and pattern of the altar, with all its specifications.
verses.comment: Models 'model and pattern' from Hebrew. 'Specifications' is explanatory addition for clarity.

verses.text: So Uriah the priest built an altar according to all that King Ahaz had sent from Damascus; Uriah the priest made it before King Ahaz came back from Damascus.
verses.comment: Maintains construction details.

verses.text: When the king came from Damascus, the king saw the altar; then the king approached the altar and offered sacrifices on it.
verses.comment: Retains order of events and direct language.

verses.text: He offered his burnt offering and his grain offering, poured out his drink offering, and sprinkled the blood of his peace offerings on the altar.
verses.comment: 'Sprinkled' matches Hebrew 'zrq'.

verses.text: He brought the bronze altar, which was before the LORD, from the front of the temple—from between his altar and the house of the LORD—and put it on the north side of his altar.
verses.comment: 'His altar' refers to Ahaz's new altar per context.

verses.text: King Ahaz commanded Uriah the priest, saying, 'On the great altar, offer the morning burnt offering, the evening grain offering, the king’s burnt offering, his grain offering, and the burnt offering of all the people of the land, their grain offering, and their drink offerings, and sprinkle on it all the blood of burnt offerings and all the blood of sacrifices. But the bronze altar shall be for me to seek guidance.'
verses.comment: Literal list of offerings kept; 'seek guidance' matches Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Uriah the priest did everything King Ahaz commanded.
verses.comment: No significant difference.

verses.text: King Ahaz cut off the frames of the stands, removed the washbasins from them; he took down the sea from the bronze oxen that supported it and set it on a stone base.
verses.comment: Matches technical details of temple furniture.

verses.text: He also removed the Sabbath canopy that had been built in the temple, and the king's entrance outside the temple, because of the king of Assyria.
verses.comment: 'Canopy' is a modern term for Hebrew 'miskan', matches context.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Ahaz that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah?
verses.comment: Conventional ending formula retained.

verses.text: So Ahaz rested with his fathers and was buried with his ancestors in the city of David. Then Hezekiah his son reigned in his place.
verses.comment: 'Rested with his fathers' kept literal; burial location clarified.
